title: Read the Platform
html:
This week I suggested the idea of a “Web Standards Book Club” on Mastodon and there was a bit of interest. After thinking about how such a club would work, I’ve decided that since I suggested the idea of the club to the fediverse, the club will take place in the fediverse.

How to participate

  1. Follow the hashtag #ReadThePlatform in the fediverse. Feel free to lurk or to secondhand read.
  2. Read books or content about the Web Platform at your own pace. Sync up with others if you’d like.
  3. Share about that content using the hashtag. Feel free to share anything you write about it on your website too.

There’s no formal meet up times, but don’t let that stop you from organizing meetups to discuss with others.

My own reading list

I’m no authority here — you can read whatever you’d like, but here is my own initial, tentative reading plan if you’d like to follow along with me:

  1. Idiosyncrasies of the HTML parser by Simon Pieters
  2. Web Browser Engineering by Pavel Panchekha & Chris Harrelson
  3. Web Platform Contribution Guide by various authors

All of these books are free to read online, open source, and in the case of the first two, you can support the writers as they continue to write their respective books. Those details can be found in the links above.

Why I’m doing this?

My own personal motivation for reading books and other content about the Web Platform is not only to deepen my understanding of the medium as it affects my work, but so that I can contribute in more ways. I’ve been inspired by individuals involved in moving the Web forward and I believe that the Web is ours and not just the product of large companies. I believe in the Web and so I am reading to ensure the Web continues to have a future, because the Web is not inevitable.
